Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Integrated Micro-Electro-Mechanical-System for Cellular Mechanotransduction Studies
Award.AbstractNarration:
Cellular mechanotransduction, the mechanism by which cells convert a mechanical stimulus into biochemical activities, widely affects a broad array of physiological processes. The mechanical stimulus is perceived and processed by cells and tissues through a highly complicated process regulated by a large number of biomolecules, subcellular components and extracellular structures, which eventually leads to appropriate biochemical responses. Understanding mechanotransduction requires engineering devices that can provide in situ assessment, in a controlled environment, of the cell response to systematically variable external mechanical stimuli mimicking the combinatorial mechanical loads (compressive/tensile) found in vivo.

In this CAREER project, fully automated cellular mechanotransduction analysis will be streamlined through the development of an integrated micro-electro-mechanical-system (MEMS). The device will simplify the analysis of cells and tissues by minimizing external influence and will provide direct correlation between an applied mechanical stimulus and the activity of critical mechanosensitive biomolecules. The device will enable application of independently controllable combinational mechanical signals with preferred magnitudes, frequency, and duration to cells on loading sites. The use of a microfluidic network will allow parallel actuation of a large number of cells, and in situ intercellular and intracellular analysis. Use of the device will be simplified by developing instrumental and software interfaces. The efficacy of the device will be evaluated using skeletal myoblasts C2C12. By enabling quantitative study mechanotrandcution pathways, the device will help in the study of mechanisms that govern physiologic and pathologic conditions of mechanosensitive cells.

The CAREER project will integrate the PI's research, education and outreach activities. The research outcome will be incorporated into courses and laboratory modules, benefitting students from both engineering fields and biology. The research discoveries will be disseminated through archival journals and conference presentations. Meanwhile, the research will provide a vehicle to deliver math, technological and engineering science in an exciting, practical, and interactive environment to minority and women students through the institutional Engineers in Motion program, and to K-12 students through collaboration with a local high school.

The project outcome will also be available at the lab website http://www.bme.ohio-state.edu/yizhao/.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF award by the Instrument Development for Biological Research (IDBR) program supports work by Professor Yi Zhao at The Ohio State University for quantitative application of mechanical signals towards living cells and quantitative assessment of the beneficial/adverse effects of these mechanical signals. The objective of this research is to design and develop micro-electro-mechanical-systems (MEMS) to address the growing need for instruments required for studying the complex and interrelated mechanotransduction events at cellular levels, and allows for investigating the effects of combinatorial mechanostimuli in living cells.

This project has implemented and disseminated an educational and training program that develops interdisciplinary modes of thoughts at the boundary of science and engineering through integrated research opportunities in biomedical micro/nanosystems. The project incorporates undergraduate/ graduate research and education at The Ohio State University, outreach to K-12 students and commercialization to benefit wide public.

The significant contribution of this work entails the following aspects: (1) Development of a microdevice for parallel application of identical or differential mechanical signals towards live cells and analysis of cellular responses on a single chip; (2) Development of a vari-thickness elastomer membrane that can apply spatially uniform equibiaxial strain to live cells upon a differential pressure across the membrane; (3) Development of a microdevice that applies controlled combinatorial active and passive mechanical stimulations to live cells and assesses cell responses; (4) Development of a microdevice that allows for the investigation of the communications among cells under different mechanical stimulations by accommodating regions with different shear stress profiles within the same culturing chamber; (5) The first demonstration of a microdevice that allows for quantitative assessment of intercellular electromechanical coupling in adult cardiomyocyte pairs. The usefulness of the microdevices was demonstrated using a wide spectrum of mechanically active cells, including trabecular meshwork endothelial cells, fibroblasts, skeletal myoblasts, cardiomyocytes, primary hippocampal neuron cells, human umbilical vein endothelial cells, endodermal cells, osteoblasts, and chondrocytes, through our collaborations with biological researchers in many different disciplines. The highly integrated micromechanical cell stimulators with versatile functions, operation simplicity, and reliability will facilitate scientific studies of highly complicated cellular mechanobiological events, making an impact on fundamental cellular biomechanics, cell-based drug discovery, and development of new cues against mechanical related disorders. In addition to the immediate impacts on cellular biomechanics and mechanobiology, the vari-thickness elastomer membrane developed in this project also finds significant use in adaptive optics. An elastomer-liquid lens with greatly reduced optical aberration was developed, which allows for microscopic imaging with a low cost and compact setting. One US patent has been issued and one provisional patent application is pending. The technology will allow for miniaturization of optical imaging systems while retaining most imaging capabilities. It supports advanced imaging using mobile devices to address the needs in consumer electronics, remote surveillance, homeland security, etc.

Given the broad interdisciplinary nature of this research, student participants have had an outstanding opportunity to work in an area that bridges fundamental engineering research, biological research, clinical needs, and medical industrial applications. Graduate student Dr. Qian Wang received his PhD through fully working on this project with his PhD thesis entitled “Elastomer-based Cellular Micromechanical Stimulators for Mechanobiological Study”. He is now a Medical Device Engineer at Bertec Corporation, a biomechanics device company. Another student Dr. Xu Zhang served as the Entrepreneur Lead of an NSF I-Corps project based on the topic in this project, and became a project manager at OSU Technology Entrepreneurship Commercialization institute after graduation with the doctoral degree. Another student Dr. Kang Wei focused on optical application of vari-thickness elastomer membrane and became a senior engineer to investigate liquid accommodating intraocular lens (IOL) at Alcon. Graduate students fully or partially working on this project have received many prestigious fellowships and awards from OSU, professional societies, and private medical foundations. In addition, several graduate and undergraduate students that participated in this project have won OSU Fisher Business Plan competitions, based on ideas spun from this project. In each year during the award period, high school students from OSU as well as other institute participated in the project. These students have become extremely valuable to the lab and almost indispensable to the key graduate students and the project. Most high school students chose STEM majors when they stepped into the college. This project has also served as an excellent vehicle for the generation of new materials for four contemporary biomedical micro/nanotechnology courses and one undergraduate biomechanics domain course taught by Professor Yi Zhao.
